Louisville's Farrell met Donovan in MLS Cup

Jonathan Lintner, jlintner@courier-journal.com 10:57 a.m. EST December 8, 2014

Landon Donovan, right, plays the ball past Louisville’s Andrew Farrell in the first half of Sunday’s MLS Cup match.(Photo: By Victor Decolongon/Getty Images)

CONNECT 5 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

Landon Donovan had a sweet sendoff Sunday as his LA Galaxy team beat the New England Revolution 2-1 in the MLS Cup. But first, one of the most-storied players in United States soccer history had to face a defense headed up by Andrew Farrell, the Atherton and University of Louisville product who went to the Revolution as the No. 1 pick in 2013.

"It's pretty special to share the field with players like that, who have done so much for the league and the sport," Farrell told Goal USA last week of Donovan and Thierry Henry, who he met in an earlier postseason game against the New York Red Bulls. "You always want to go against the best, and challenge yourself against the best. Obviously they're not in their 20s and in their prime, but they're still pretty darn good and it's still a tough task because even at their ages you aren't going to completely shut those guys down."

A ProSoccerTalk.com analysis of the MLS Cup evidenced the Galaxy's game plan Sunday: to go at Farrell and fellow Revolution defender A.J. Soares on the right side of the field. The duo is "a pair of young, promising, up-and-down performers opponents frequently target," wrote NBC's Andy Edwards.

COURIER-JOURNAL

Louisville City FC moves supporter seating at Slugger Field

Gyasi Zardes scored the game's opening goal by targeting Farrell, part of an 11-man Revolution lineup on which none had MLS Cup experience. Later in the game, Farrell got in solid position, had a chance at an equalizer but fired a square shot at the Galaxy's goalkeeper.

One game won't define Farrell's career, though.

Heading into Sunday, Revolution goalkeeper Bobby Shuttleworth told Goal USA that it's as if Farrell has "played a lot of years in the league already."

"He came in pretty ready," said coach Jay Heaps of Farrell, who played three seasons at U of L, winning Big East Player of the Year and First Team All-American honors. "He's as good a rookie last year as I've seen, and as good a complete player. Andrew Farrell's been excellent since day one.

"I really enjoy how much he competes. That's what gets lost in it. He's a roll-up-your-sleeves kind of guy. He loves training, he loves practices, he loves games and you love seeing that from a player."

COURIER-JOURNAL

Louisville City FC hardly alone in MLS dreams

IN THE C-J

•Writing Sunday from the KFC Yum! Center, where the Kentucky women's team rallied to beat U of L for the third straight year, columnist Adam Himmelsbach insists this rivalry — played in front of nearly 15,000 — should mean more than most games. And that's even if the Cards' and Cats' coaches won't admit it. (http://cjky.it/1qjSm3O)

•A U of L-Georgia Belk Bowl matchup stirs a number of story lines — another SEC matchup and Todd Grantham meeting his old team among them — but how the Cardinals ended up in Charlotte rather than a number of other destinations capped a zany college footall Sunday. (http://cjky.it/1CWmDeE)

•We're prepping early for U of L's Jimmy V. Classic matchup with Indiana on Tuesday night, where fans are already weighing in with predictions. Hoosiers fans are showing up strong and have the edge so far. (http://cjky.it/1qjStfQ)

AROUND THE WEB

•Charlotte Observer columnist Andrew Carter, answering a piece by Lexington columnist John Clay, wrote over the weekend "A response to Kentucky's love letter to UNC, Duke," in which he stated that John Calipari's entire system "seems cheap, taking advantage of a rule that shouldn't exist." (http://bit.ly/12i43Ns)

•Before UK played EKU on Sunday night — and that wouldn't likely factor into this sort of thing anyway — CBS Sports' Gary Parrish asked an odds maker what sort of line he'd assign to UK and Duke on a neutral court. Todd Fuhrman says UK -4.5. (http://bit.ly/1wp6ETn)

•Cardinals fans, we have a must-follow for you a day before U of L and Indiana meet at Madison Square Garden. Zach Osterman (@ZachOsterman on Twitter) covers the Hoosiers diligently for our sister paper, The Indianapolis Star, and offered up some thoughts on IU's depth. (http://indy.st/1vw4udK)

Jonathan Lintner can be reached at (502) 582-4199. Follow him on Twitter @JonathanLintner.
